metadata.title: The CuZnZrAl hydroxycarbonates as copper catalyst precursors—Structure, thermal decomposition and reduction studies

Sample S BET (m2/g) S Cu (m2/g) Cu (wt.%) S Cu (m2/gCu) 1 CuZnZrAl_2_4_0 75.2 13.7 45.7 30.0 2 CuZnZrAl_2_4_1 114.2 17.7 42.6 41.5 3 CuZnZrAl_2_4_3 126.1 15.5 41.1 37.6 4 CuZnZrAl_2_4_∞ 108.5 10.0 40.3 24.8 5 CuZnZrAl_2_2_1 141.4 11.8 35.7 33.1 6 CuZnZrAl_2_1_1 112.4 4.9 27.4 18.0 7 CuZnZrAl_2_0.5_1 236.7 4.7 18.7 26.2 The CuZnZrAl hydroxycarbonates as copper catalyst precursors—Structure, thermal decomposition and reduction studies Paweł Kowalik ⁎ Marcin Konkol Małgorzata Kondracka Wiesław Próchniak Robert Bicki Paweł Wiercioch Fertilizer Research Institute, Catalyst Research Department, Al. Tysiąclecia Państwa Polskiego 13A, 24-110 Puławy, Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +48 81 473 1441. Graphical abstract Highlights ► HT-XRD studies of two series of complex CuZnZrAl hydroxycarbonates as copper catalyst precursors. ► Influence of the Zr/Al ratio on the formation of hydrotalcite-like phases of the CuZnAl hydroxycarbonates. ► With increasing ZrO2 content CuO crystallites form at higher temperatures during calcination. ► Decrease of CuO crystallite size at the calcination temperatures up to ca. 400°C upon addition of zirconium oxide. The transformations of a series of complex CuZnZrAl hydroxycarbonates as copper catalyst precursors have been investigated. The materials have been prepared by the coprecipitation method and characterized by means of XRD, ICP-OES, TG-MS, TPR and N2O chemisorption. The results reveal that the Zr/Al ratio has got an influence on the formation of hydrotalcite-like phases of copper–zinc–aluminum hydroxycarbonates. The increase of ZrO2 content results in the increase of amorphous phase content in the hydroxycarbonate precursors. Moreover, the increase of ZrO2 content causes the formation of CuO crystallites at higher temperatures during calcination. At the lower calcination temperatures (up to ca. 400°C) the incorporation of zirconium oxide results in the decrease of CuO crystallite size in the calcined mixed oxides compared to the Zr-free sample. At higher calcination temperatures a reversed effect was observed. Two different thermal decomposition pathways of the precursors with and without alumina were observed. Keywords Copper catalyst precursor Methanol synthesis CuZnZrAl hydroxycarbonates Mixed metal oxides XRD studies 1 Introduction The copper–zinc systems, having highly dispersed copper have found their wide application as catalysts [1,2] or sorbents [3] in many important chemical processes. The CuZnAl catalysts are especially important, being a basis of modern methanol synthesis technologies [4] and methanol-to-hydrogen conversion processes [5,6]. In industrial practice the most often used are the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3-type catalysts, but there have been many studies on the modification of a catalyst formula in order to achieve higher activity and better stability of the catalysts [7,8]. According to the literature data, the most promising and interesting in the methanol synthesis are the coprecipitated copper catalysts of a type Cu/ZnO, additionally modified with metal oxides (aluminum, zirconium, lanthanum and magnesium) [9]. The nature of an active component in the methanol synthesis process is very complex [10,11] and has not been fully elucidated. There is a general hypothesis that the reaction proceeds on a partially reduced copper Cu0–Cu+, copper species decorated with zinc or in a Cu–O–Zn system. This is proved by the fact that a strong correlation between the copper active surface area and the catalytic activity is observed [12,13]. Highly dispersed copper is achieved in course of the appropriate preparation and activation of the abovementioned catalytic system, with a careful control of the conditions being crucial for the quality of a final catalyst. Coprecipitation and further activation of a precursor is a dominant technique for the preparation of CuZnAl catalysts. It is due to its simplicity and high yields obtained. The preparation of the Cu/ZnO catalysts includes three steps: (a) synthesis of a hydroxycarbonate precursor by coprecipitation method, (b) thermal decomposition of the precursor to the oxide form, (Cu a Zn b Al c Zr d )(CO3) x (OH) y → aCuO+ bZnO+(1/2)cAl2O3 + dZrO2 + xCO2↑+ yH2O ΔH >0 (c) reduction of the copper oxide to the final active catalyst form. CuO+H2 →Cu+H2O ΔH =−80.8kJ/mol The composition and structure of the precursor as well as the parameters of its thermal treatment have a remarkable influence on the activity of the final catalyst [14]. In course of the preparation it is desirable to obtain highly dispersed copper [15]. It is, however, difficult due to the copper properties, most of all its low melting point and, in consequence, its tendency for recrystallization [16]. One of the ways to improve the copper thermostability and therefore to extend a period of the catalyst effective performance is the formula modification. Some promising results have been obtained by modification with zirconia of the standard Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 system [17–19]. The catalysts modified with zirconia exhibit higher catalytic activity under the conditions of a typical methanol synthesis process. What is even more important they are more effective in the conversion of syngases enriched in CO2 to methanol [19,20]. The processes concomitant with the transformations of the CuZnAl precursors modified with zirconia to the final catalyst form have been rather poorly elucidated. There is a lack of a complex studies on this kind of catalytic systems. On the contrary, the properties of conventional CuZnAl precursors [21] are well documented due to the potential possibility of obtaining from them complex homogeneous oxide systems with very good catalytic properties [22]. The studies on the Cu/ZnO catalytic systems concentrate mainly on the methods of their preparation [23], structure characterization and description [24,25], kinetic studies and physicochemical properties [26,27]. The investigations on the calcination processes are focused mainly on the influence of the thermal conditions on the properties of the catalysts obtained [28,29]. There are only few contributions on the mechanisms of transformations during thermal decomposition of these systems. The investigations of Frost et al. [30] on calcination in the temperature range of 30–500°C, which are limited only to the precursors having a stoichiometric hydrotalcite-like composition, Cu x Zn(6−x)Al2(OH)16CO3·4H2O and a molar ratio (Cu2+ +Zn2+)/Al3+ =3, with variable copper and zinc content (0≤ x ≤6), reveal a multistep decomposition process consisting of several stages such as loss of adsorbed water, dehydroxylation and carbonate groups decomposition [31,32]. This contribution is an attempt of filling a gap in the area of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 systems modified with zirconium oxide, having a potential application as methanol synthesis catalysts. The objective of this work is a qualitative description of the CuZnZrAl precursors with a wide range of the chemical composition as well as of their thermal decomposition and activation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation Two series of CuZnZrAl hydroxycarbonate precursors covering a wide range of chemical composition were prepared by the coprecipitation method. Precursors of the first series have got the same molar ratios of Cu/Zn=2 and (Cu+Zn)/(Al+Zr)=4 but a variable Zr/Al molar ratio. The second series covered the precursors with the same molar ratios of Cu/Zn=2 and Zr/Al=1 and a variable (Cu+Zn)/(Al+Zr) ratio. Aqueous solutions of copper, zinc and aluminum nitrates (POCh Gliwice, Poland), a solution of zirconyl nitrate (Sigma Aldrich) and a solution of sodium carbonate were added slowly to a beaker with 150ml of redistilled water heated up to 65–70°C. The reaction temperature was kept in the given range and the pH value of the resulting suspension was maintained in the range of 7–7.4. Under these conditions a precursor deposited that was aged during intensive stirring for 1h. In the next step the sodium and nitrate ions were thoroughly removed by washing out with redistilled water. Decantation of the material was followed by drying at 105°C for 20h. 2.2 Chemical composition Chemical compositions of precursors were determined by means of ICP-OES using a Varian 720-ES spectrometer. 2.3 Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) The XRD measurements were performed on a PANalytical Empyrean system (Bragg–Brentano geometry) equipped with a PIXcel3D detector using Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.542Å) and operating at 40kV and 40mA. The samples were scanned between 5<2θ <65°, with the step size 0.0525° and time/step of 70.125s. The crystallite size was calculated using the Scherrer equation (d = Kλ/β cos θ, where K is the Scherrer equation constant, λ is the wavelength of radiation, β is the line broadening of the XRD peak, and θ is the diffraction angle). The line broadening of CuO was used and a correction for instrumental broadening was carried out with a reference diffraction (LaB6). Temperature-programmed XRD measurements were carried out in an Anton Paar HTK-16N chamber. The sample was deposited as a thin layer (ca. 0.1mm) on a Pt heating strip. A Pt/Pt–13%Rh thermocouple spot-welded to the bottom of the heating strip was used for measuring the temperature. The XRD measurements reported were conducted in air. In situ XRD patterns were recorded isothermally at intervals of 100°C in the temperature range of 25–800°C with increasing temperature. The calculation of theoretical X-ray powder patterns, Rietveld analysis and crystallite size refinement were done using a Highscore Plus software. A diffraction line CuO d(111) was selected for the calculation of the copper oxide crystallite size. Microstructural changes of the CuZnZrAl precursors under temperature changes were elucidated by a detailed line profile analysis of the X-ray diffraction patterns. The X-ray diffraction patterns were refined with a sum of pseudo-Voigt profile functions and an appropriate background function. 2.4 Thermogravimetry (TG-MS) Thermogravimetric measurements were carried out using a Netzsch STA 449 Jupiter thermal analyzer coupled with a QMS 430C Aëolos mass spectrometer. For the measurements a sample of ca. 20mg was used. The measurements were performed in a helium stream, raising the sample temperature to 700°C with a rate of 10°C/min. During the measurement changes of the sample weight and m/z signals (m/z =18 and m/z =44) were constantly monitored. 2.5 Reducibility For temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) a sample (30mg) was placed into a U-shaped quartz tube under a flow of reduction mixture 6%H2/Ar. The U-tube was placed in an electrically heated furnace and the temperature of the sample was gradually increased (5°C/min) to 400°C. The measurements conditions were optimized, and criterion number “k” was in the range of 55< k <140 [33]. 2.6 Specific surface and copper surface area The specific surface area of the samples was determined by measuring nitrogen adsorption at the temperature of liquid nitrogen and p/p 0 =0.05–0.3 using a Micromeritics ASAP® 2050 Xtended Pressure sorption analyzer. For precursors calcined at 300°C and reduced in 6%H2/He mixture at 250°C measurements of active copper surface area were carried out using chemisorption of N2O – impulse technique [34–36]. Nitrous oxide reacts with surface metallic copper with evolution of nitrogen. The amount of nitrogen generated is proportional to the copper surface area. 2Cu+N2O→Cu–O–Cu+N2 The following surface oxide stoichiometry and density of surface copper atoms were assumed: Cu/O=2 and 1.46×1019 at/m2, respectively. 3 Results and discussion The chemical composition of the CuZnZrAl precursors used in this study is summarized in Table 1 . The bulk structure of copper in various CuZnZrAl precursors was studied under temperature changes by means of in situ HT-XRD. The XRD diffraction pattern changes of the CuZnZrAl precursors as a function of calcination temperature in the temperature range of 25–800°C are shown in Fig. 1 . As an example a detailed description of the phases for the CuZnZrAl_2_4_1 precursor is provided in Fig. 2 . 3.1 XRD patterns of the precursors The stoichiometry of the substrates used determines the Cu4Zn2Al2(OH)16(CO3)·4H2O stoichiometry of a precursor. Such a well-crystalline hydrotalcite-like phase can be observed for the CuZnZrAl_2_4_0 precursor without zirconium oxide. In the case of the CuZnZrAl_2_4_1 precursor, due to the diffraction line broadening of the corresponding peaks and the presence of other hydroxycarbonates, hydrotalcite-type solids with a general formula Cu x Zn6−x Al2(OH)16(CO3)·4H2O should also be considered. The typical XRD pattern of the Cu–Zn hydrotalcite-like structure, Cu x Zn6−x Al2(OH)16(CO3)·4H2O (ICDD 37-629, 37-630, 38-486, 38-487) can be described as a series of very similar diffraction lines with the highest intensity at 2θ =11.7°, 23.4°, 34.6° and 46.7°, corresponding to the d values of 7.57, 3.80, 2.60 and 1.94Å. Each layer is constituted of edge-linked M(OH)6 octahedra, where M is a divalent metal such as e.g. Zn or Cu. The preparation of the catalysts from hydrotalcites has such an advantage that it generates, after calcination and reduction, nanoparticles of metallic copper intimately dispersed among Zn and Al oxides [37,38]. In the case of the CuZnZrAl_2_4_0 precursor a malachite phase, Cu2(CO3)(OH)2 (ICDD 4-11-5196) was also observed. For the CuZnZrAl_2_4_1 precursor the remaining diffraction peaks were assigned to two other phases: rosasite, mixed copper–zinc hydroxycarbonate (Cu,Zn)2(CO3)(OH)2 (ICDD 36-1475) and malachite, Cu2(CO3)(OH)2. Although one diffraction peak at 2θ ∼33° could not be unequivocally assigned to the abovementioned phases, other authors postulate the assignment to the rosasite phase [31]. Moreover, it should be considered that the rosasite phase can be described as a solid solution, in which the Cu/Zn ratio can influence the intensities of the diffraction peaks in the XRD pattern. The CuZnZrAl_2_4_3 precursor is characterized by poorly formed crystallographic phases. The large widths of the diffraction lines and the presence of overlapping peaks suggest that these species are well dispersed [39], which is considered beneficial for the synergy between Cu and Zn. The XRD pattern is characterized by broad uniform diffraction lines of low intensity at 2θ =12.16° and 34.90°. In the crystallographic phase composition one can distinguished dispersed phases of mixed copper–zinc–aluminum hydroxycarbonates of hydrotalcite-like type, Cu x Zn(6−x)Al2(OH)16(CO3)·4H2O as well as a phase of zinc hydroxycarbonate, Zn2Al(OH)6(CO3)0.5·H2O (56-955). For the CuZnZrAl_2_4_∞ precursor, which was prepared without alumina, two crystallographic phases were found: malachite, Cu2(CO3)(OH)2 (ICDD 4-11-5196) and aurichalcite, Cu2Zn3(CO3)2(OH)6 (ICDD 4-10-3227). The XRD powder patterns of CuZnZrAl_2_2_1 and CuZnZrAl_2_1_1 precursors are very similar to the CuZnZrAl_2_4_1 precursor. Based on a comparison of intensities of dominant phases one can conclude that in the CuZnZrAl_2_2_1 precursor the content of the hydrotalcite-like phase is lower than the rosasite one. Only traces of the malachite phase were found. For the samples CuZnZrAl_2_1_1 and CuZnZrAl_2_0.5_1 with a low content of Cu+Zn practically no crystalline phases were observed. The XRD patterns of all zirconium-containing precursors revealed no crystalline phases of zirconium. 3.2 XRD patterns of the calcined oxides The first XRD pattern of the CuZnZrAl_2_4_1 precursor collected at 25°C showed a hydrotalcite-like structure with characteristic diffraction lines at 2θ =11.7°, 23.4°, 34.6° and 46.7°. In the course of temperature-programmed measurements at about 300°C the peak intensity decreased rapidly and the hydrotalcite-like phase diffraction pattern began to disappeared. On further temperature increase, the characteristic CuO diffraction peaks at 2θ =ca. 35° and ca. 39° were observed. Above 400°C the ongoing growth of CuO particles took place, indicated by the more pronounced and narrowest reflections. The calcined precursor exhibited the characteristic diffraction lines for CuO in the XRD profile. The reflections were very broad, indicating an ill-defined crystalline phase, probably overlapping with the broad ZnO reflections. ZrO2 appeared to be almost X-ray amorphous in the temperature range up to 700°C. No diffraction lines corresponding to aluminum compounds were observed. This suggests that the aluminum compounds were either amorphous or highly dispersed. Similar phase transformations take place in the case of precursor samples with a constant (Cu+Zn)/(Al+Zr)=4 ratio and a variable Zr/Al ratio. In the case of the CuZnZrAl_2_4_3 sample calcination results in the development of the CuO phase at the temperature of 400°C. Only at 600°C one can observe the sintering of copper oxide crystallites, and above the temperature of 700°C separate phases: CuO, ZnO and ZrO2 were confirmed. For the CuZnZrAl_2_4_∞ sample without alumina, calcination leads to the formation of copper oxide crystallites at 400°C, and the crystalline phases of ZnO and ZrO2 appear at temperatures of 500 and 600°C, respectively. At 800°C traces of a spinel, ZnAl2O4 were observed. These results can be compared with those for the CuZnZrAl_2_4_0 sample without zirconium oxide, where the appearance of the crystalline CuO phase can be observed already between 300 and 400°C. One can conclude that the presence of ZrO2 in a sample may delay the crystallization and sintering of CuO in a catalyst. The decrease of the (Cu+Zn)/(Al+Zr) ratio (samples CuZnZrAl_2_2_1, CuZnZrAl_2_1_1, CuZnZrAl_2_0.5_1) results in the decrease of the crystalline phase/amorphous phase ratio. The broad diffraction lines and the presence of overlapping reflection peaks suggest well dispersion of the species. The increased content of ZrO2 in the samples CuZnZrAl_2_2_1, CuZnZrAl_2_1_1 results in the formation of CuO crystallites at higher calcination temperatures (700–800°C). The size of copper oxide crystallites at various temperatures is compared in Fig. 3 and summarized in Table 2 . The average crystallite size of the sample CuZnZrAl_2_4_1 was the smallest at the temperature of 400°C, whereas for the sample CuZnZrAl_2_4_0 without zirconia the largest crystallites form at this temperature. Additionally, copper oxide crystallite size depends on the Zr/Al molar ratio in the entire range of temperatures. Above the temperature 500°C CuO crystallites in the sample without zirconia are smaller than those for all other samples modified with zirconia and with the variable Zr/Al ratio. This finding confirms that the precursors should be calcined in the rigorous temperature range and that increasing of calcination temperature favors the CuO recrystallization. At elevated temperature copper and its oxides undergo gradual recrystallization. The tendency for recrystallization of a given substance is described by two parameters that are directly related to the melting temperature (T m): Hüttig temperature (T H =0.3 T m) and Tamman temperature (T T =0.5 T m) [40]. At T H temperature the atoms mobility at surface defects becomes greater, further increase of the temperature to T T leads to the increase of atoms mobility in the bulk and at the melting temperature the mobility will be so high that liquid-phase behavior is observed. As a consequence of low melting temperature of copper and copper oxide, the temperature, at which surface migration of atoms and clusters may occur, is relatively low. The T m, T T and T H parameters for the components of the CuZnZrAl catalytic systems are summarized in Table 3 . The data presented reveal that the surface mobility of copper atoms takes place at the temperature range ca. 400°C. From our observation it looks that, despite the significant participation of ZnO and Al2O3, the CuZnAl systems should not be treated at temperatures above ∼350–400°C. In turn, the addition of ZrO2 causes that the intensity of CuO recrystallization increases above 500°C. Zirconium and aluminum oxides, especially zirconium oxide have much higher melting points, therefore playing a role of structural modifiers by preventing the sintering processes of CuO crystallites and in a similar way of Cu. 3.3 Thermal analysis of the materials The progress of calcination of the CuZnZrAl precursors is shown on the DTG curves (Fig. 4A) and the MS curves corresponding to the signals from CO2 and H2O (Fig. 4B). Both the DTG and MS curves show similar pattern for all precursors investigated except CuZnZrAl_2_4_∞, that means the one without alumina. During calcination of all samples the presence of weight loss steps over the low-temperature (120–160°C) and medium-temperature (200–380°C) ranges as well as of the high-temperature weight loss step (above 450°C) of low intensity was observed. Varying the (Cu+Zn)/(Zr+Al)mol ratio in the system (Cu/Zn and Zr/Al=const.), two well-formed bands over low- and medium-temperature ranges were observed. The decrease of this ratio results in a shift of a dominant decomposition band toward lower temperatures. On the other hand, the increase of the zirconium oxide content, Zr/Al ratio at a fixed (Cu+Zn)/(Zr+Al)=4 ratio also results in a change of the intensity of the individual decomposition steps and a shift of the dominant band toward higher temperatures. The MS data (Fig. 4B) show that with the increasing temperature, besides elimination of initial moisture and weakly bound water (max. at 170–200°C), decomposition processes with H2O as a product occur. This reveals partial but very intensive decomposition of OH− groups in hydroxycarbonates. It seems that two kinds of hydroxy groups can be distinguished in the precursors investigated because of the presence on the MS curves of the second MS18 band with a maximum in the temperature range of 230–250°C. In this range the processes running with CO2 evolution take also place, which reveals a simultaneous decomposition of carbonate groups. The highest intensity of CO2 generating decomposition processes are observed in the high-temperature range (max. at 500–600°C), that is in the range, where carbonates underwent complete decomposition. This is particularly clearly seen for the CuZnZrAl_2_4_∞ precursor, for which a different course of decomposition process compared to other samples can be observed. In this case the extent of weight loss steps over the temperature range until 300°C (both for DTG as well as MS18 and MS44) is very low, and the decomposition process proceeds in several steps between 350 and 500°C. The results of TPR measurements of the precursors after calcination at 300°C for 4h are shown in Fig. 5 . In the case of all samples investigated at least two reduction bands are observed, indicating a complex form of the active copper precursor. Three main reduction ranges can be distinguished on the TPR profiles. In the light of literature data on the reduction of high-copper CuZnAl systems the following interpretation can be put forward: • 150–180°C – partial reduction Cu2+ →Cu+ [41], • sharp bands in the range of 180–210°C – reduction of well-crystallized CuO and CuAl2O4 – type forms [42,43], • broad reduction bands >210°C – reduction of Cu2+ ions dissolved in ZnO [41] and, possibly, also traces of hydroxycarbonates not decomposed during the precursor calcination [44]. The intensity of the reduction bands is related to the chemical composition. In the case of the CuZnZrAl_2_0.5_1 precursor with the lowest copper content and the highest total content of Al2O3 and ZrO2 two reduction bands can be observed: a narrow band (max. at 210°C) of relatively high intensity and a weak, broad, high-temperature band with a maximum at 285°C. The increase of the molar ratio (Cu+Zn)/(Zr+Al) results in the increase of intensity of the high-temperature band and its shift toward lower temperatures (270°C for CuZnZrAl_2_1_1 and 220°C for CuZnZrAl_2_2_1). With further increase of the ratio a single reduction band of a high intensity with a maximum at 195°C can be observed. The data presented also reveal that the lower Zr/Al ratio at a fixed (Cu+Zn)/(Zr+Al)=4 ratio results in the formation of CuO species, for which reduction is more difficult and the reduction processes run in several stages in a way similar to the reduction of systems with a low content of copper and high of ZrO2. Moreover, reduction of copper oxide proceeds the most easily, that means at the lowest temperature and only in two stages, for the alumina-free precursor, CuZnZrAl_2_4_∞. The increase of alumina content in a precursor causes the decrease of the content of easily reducible active copper precursor forms. The intensity of the low-temperature processes is lower and the reduction to a large extent proceeds in the higher temperature range. Table 4 shows the texture characteristics for oxide forms obtained via calcination of CuZnZrAl precursors at 300°C for 4h. The data reveal that the value of the specific surface area of resulting oxide forms is in a wide range. As it can be expected, the specific surface area of oxide forms of CuZnZrAl precursors increases with the increasing total (Zr+Al) content. The highest value was found for the products of thermal decomposition of the CuZnZrAl_2_0.5_1 precursor, the one with the highest ZrO2 content. The copper surface area of the samples after reduction is in the range of 4.7–17.7m2 Cu/gcat. Within the range of investigated compositions the influence of chemical composition, including the copper content on the copper active surface area is low. What is really essential is the fact that the presence of two structural modifiers such as ZrO2 and Al2O3 favors the increase of copper surface area, which amounts to 18–41.5m2/gCu. 4 Conclusions (a) The Zr/Al ratio has got an influence on the formation of hydrotalcite-like phases of copper–zinc–aluminum hydroxycarbonates. A lack of alumina in the system leads to the formation of malachite as the main phase together with aurichalcite. Upon decreasing the molar ratio (Cu+Zn)/(Zr+Al), precursors with a decreasing content of a crystalline phase were obtained. In XRD patterns of the precursors no crystalline phases of zirconium compounds were found. (b) The increase of ZrO2 content causes the formation of CuO crystallites at higher temperatures during calcination. At the lower calcination temperatures (up to ca. 400°C) the incorporation of zirconium oxide results in the decrease of CuO crystallite size in the calcined mixed oxides compared to the Zr-free sample. At higher calcination temperatures a reversed effect was observed. (c) The copper oxide crystallite size depends on the addition of the modifiers. With the increasing of the Zr/Al ratio the increase of CuO crystallite size can be observed. (d) Mixed hydroxycarbonates of copper, zinc and aluminum undergo multi-step thermal decomposition. The essential step with almost complete water and hydroxycarbonate elimination and decomposition of the carbonate groups proceeds at the temperature of 300°C. The thermal decomposition of the precursor without alumina is different and proceeds in several steps, mainly above 300°C. (e) Independently of the participation of individual components, the reduction of mixed CuZnZrAl oxides takes place at higher temperature and via more steps than in the case of mixed ternary oxides, CuZnAl or CuZnZr. (f) The specific surface area of mixed ex-hydroxycarbonate CuZnZrAl oxides depends most of all on the total (Zr+Al) ratio. The higher this ratio, the greater is the specific surface area of the oxide CuZnZrAl systems. (g) No distinct correlation between the copper content and copper surface area was observed. The highest value of active copper surface area was found for the system with a relatively high copper content and modified both with Zr and Al. In the case of systems with only one type of a modifier the active copper surface area was significantly smaller. coredata.dc:description: The transformations of a series of complex CuZnZrAl hydroxycarbonates as copper catalyst precursors have been investigated. The materials have been prepared by the coprecipitation method and characterized by means of XRD, ICP-OES, TG-MS, TPR and N2O chemisorption. The results reveal that the Zr/Al ratio has got an influence on the formation of hydrotalcite-like phases of copper–zinc–aluminum hydroxycarbonates. The increase of ZrO2 content results in the increase of amorphous phase content in the hydroxycarbonate precursors. Moreover, the increase of ZrO2 content causes the formation of CuO crystallites at higher temperatures during calcination. At the lower calcination temperatures (up to ca. 400°C) the incorporation of zirconium oxide results in the decrease of CuO crystallite size in the calcined mixed oxides compared to the Zr-free sample. At higher calcination temperatures a reversed effect was observed. Two different thermal decomposition pathways of the precursors with and without alumina were observed.
coredata.dc:title: The CuZnZrAl hydroxycarbonates as copper catalyst precursors—Structure, thermal decomposition and reduction studies
